bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 8, 1900

div1.p: Reed remarks on Bryan's defeat in the United States presidential election. He describes various people at the camp. He discusses his work on yellow fever, including the possibility of human experimentation.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 8, 1900
div1.p:
Well,
isn't it a comfort
to know that that wide-
mouthed Mr Bryan is
completely snowed un-
der, and that even his
own state has gone
back on him, so that
he can't go to the Senate!
I'll declare that I feel
almost like going out
and taking a drink!
on second thought I'll
just enjoy a quiet chuck-
le all to myself- It didn't
take me long to get set-
tled down in my old
Quarters - and I am just
as comfortable as ever.
I saw General Wood
on my arrival & had
a long talk with him
as to our future work.
He looks splendidly and
is taking an intense in-
terest in the outcome
of our further observations
I reported to Gen. Lee
yesterday morning and told
him that I thought his
going away from Cuba
was an outrage - that
Cuba wouldn't seem
like Cuba without him-
He said that he had asked
to be given a station
in the U.S- that he
felt that he had been
here long enough -
I am very glad to say
that Dr & Mrs. Kean will
remain here at Colum-
bia Barracks- Dr Kean
prefers to stay in Cuba
& keep his majority to
going to the U.S. & becom-
ing an ass't. Surg. with
the rank of Captain-
He will take Dr Starks
place here; the latter
going to Matansaz --
I am, of course, sorry to
see Dr & Mrs. Stark go-
but I guess they won't
leave before January-
You should see their two
darling little boys- They
are two cunning & dear
for any thing, as they sit
side by side and wide in
their little goat-cart.
Mrs Kean is here with
Martha and little “Bobbie”,
a very pretty baby boy-
I only saw her for a
glympse this morning-
Friday night Nov. 9th- You would
hardly believe that it was
to could be so cold and chilly
in Cuba during the early
part of November- You must
have had a real norther
in the U.S- Yesterday morn-
ing at 6.30, the temperature
was 66°- which we consider
cold! Joking aside, I feel
sure that this weather will
materially reduce the cases
of yellow fever in Havana:
I sincerely hope so- In a
few days our observation
camp will be in good
shape- We have selected
a sight about 2 miles from
Quemados in quite an iso-
lated spot- Dr Ames will
be in charge of the Camp-
Whether we will be able
to carry out further observa-
tions will depend upon
our ability to get immigrants
who are willing to under-
take the risk of being bitten.
I shall devote my time to
laboratory work & study
of stained sections of the
mosquito for the discovery,
if possible, of the parasite-
I'll tell you about it, as
the work progresses-
Don't worry about me one
bit, for I shall take no
risks. When I got here, I
found three darling letters
from sweet Room - fixer, and
two type-written letters from
precious cocoon- I read
them with as much interest
as if they were new and had
only just arrived- Little Joy's
letters were remarkably
well written- She is a pre-
cious, darling child, mother,
dear, and you must help her
all you can with her studies,
as I know you will-

Saturday morning - nov. 10th- I am
up before 7 o'clock, in order
to add a line or two- The
Thermometer stands at 63° and
I am almost frozen! It is
perfectly astonishing how cold
this temperature feels here, while
in the States we wouldn't notice
it- I do hope that all of our
fruit trees ordered from Black
won't freeze en route to
Blue Ridge- Last night, I called
on the Keans and on Gen. Baldwin-
Mrs. Baldwin is very pleasant-
The people here, officers and
ladies are very much interested
in the mosquito - theory and I
am plied with questions right
and left- Do pray write often
and tell me all the news 1218-
Did Miss Carry return? Poor
girl, how sorry I felt for her
that night- If you wrote on Sunday,
your letter didn't arrive in Wednesday's
mail- But I am expecting one or
two letters, this morning, from my precious
children- Love & kisses for my girls- Be
good, sweet girls- Boo! Boo!
